traits.high_priestly_status: Named alongside Caiaphas in connection with the high priesthood, indicating a leading figure within the Jerusalem priestly establishment.
traits.background_reference: Appears in the temporal and political framing of John the Baptist’s ministry, situating that ministry within a specific high-priestly regime.
traits.association_with_early_opposition: Linked to the circle of rulers, elders, and scribes who later interrogate Peter and John after the healing of the lame man.
traits.family_and_power: Represents a powerful priestly family whose influence extends into the early chapters of the church’s story.

traits.family_connections: Identified as the father-in-law of Caiaphas, the high priest that year, linking two high-priestly households.
traits.role_in_jesus_arrest_and_hearing: Jesus is brought first to Annas for questioning after his arrest, before being sent on to Caiaphas.
traits.interrogation_focus: Questions Jesus about his disciples and teaching, presenting him as an initial examiner in the passion proceedings.
traits.narrative_function: Serves to emphasize the entanglement of Jesus’s fate with the Jerusalem high-priestly elite before the Roman trial.
